para:advertisement: Begins: ""There cannot be a stronger argument against the charge of degeneracy in moral virtue and religion brough against the present age, than the avidity with which all works exposing the breaches of them by the unerring proof of facts, are read by all people; as it can proceed only from consciousness of our own being innocent of the crimes charged upon others, and an honest exultation in the superiority which that innocent gives us over the guilty, however dear they may be to us in other respects."" ""N.B. The editor\'s absence from town, when the work went to press, having occasioned a few errours, it is humbly hoped, that as they do not materially affect the sense, the reader will pardon and correct them.""

para:preface: ""I have written this tale, for the purpose of showing how people talk, when they are not talking for display; when they are telling a story of themselves, familiarly; seated about their own fireside; with a plenty of apples and cider; in the depth of winter [...]"
para:dedication: ""May this book, in which thou wilt recognise the wayward journeying of a disposition, known only to thyself, contribute, in some degree, to gladden the winter of thy old age, and make pleasant the last dreaming of thy son."
para:advertisement: ""I have adopted this title, not to set people together by the ears, about the pronunciation; but, because it appeared to me, particularly appropriate."

para:dedication: ""My Lord, it is the custom of mankind to follow the fortunes of a great man, as long as they continue to be a support to his dependants...."
para:advertisement: ""If any reader should imagine by my comparing the Otipolian religion to a maypole, that I have as little piety as the author of the first tale of a tub; these are to inform him, that the satyr is only levell\'d at those, who seem to value the essentials of their faith no more than a maypole, and prefer one ceremony of human intuition, to twenty rules of morality and good life."
para:intro: ""Before we begin our history, we shall, according to form, fix an introduction to it, thinking that much properer than a preface; for when you would be acquainted with any one, you do not say preface me to such an one - no - but introduce me - "

para:dedication: ""To the Major General Lafayette, the venerated hero of two generations, the beloved friend and fellow soldier of the illustrious Washington: the fearless and steady defender of oppressed humanity: the purest and most consistent of republicans: the noblest and most disinterested of patriots: these volumes, descriptive of events, supposed to have occured near the memorale closing scene of that glorious drama, in which he bore so honourable and conspicuous a part, are respectfully inscribed by an individual of the nation in whose defence he lent the voluntary aid of a brave arm, and  a chivalrous spirit; and whose liberties sealed with the blood of the wise and great, he under providence was one of the chief instruments in achieving."

pub transcribed: Published by Joseph Cushing. WM. Wooddy, Printer.
pub cataloger notes: Footnotes throughout the paratext ""Review." | Library bookplates on front paste-down endpaper of both volumes, and library marginalia in pencil on recto of Dedication and verso of title page. | Every chapter has an epigraph.
para:dedication: The page reads: ""Dedication. To his country women, the author, who is an american, respectfully dedicates this work."
para:to the reader: ""I had half a mind to dedicate this novel to myself, it would have given me such an opportunity to be civil you know; and again, I was strongly inclined to get a list of all the great men in our country; of all our naval and military heroes, statesmen and divines; of every body, in fact, who could afford to pay for a compliment, and then dedicate a chapter to each, with an elegant recapitulation of all their achievements and titles; but, unfortunately I found my plan was not original; others had done it before me, or were about doing it; and so, I gave it up."
para:footnotes: Explanatory footnotes throughout Review.

para:to the reader: ""Having, by a train of fortunate circumstances, accomplished a voyage, of which the history of mankind affords no example; having, moreover, exerted every faculty of body and mind, to make my adventures useful to my countrymen, and even to mankind, by imparting to them the acquisition of secrets in physics and morals, of which they had not the faintest conception,--I flattered myself that both in the character of traveller and public benefactor, I had earned for myself an immortal name."

title full: Ismene and Ismenias, a novel. Translated from the French by L. H. Le Moine, Esq: first valet de chambre of his most Christian majesty.
title half: Ismene and Ismenias.
pub transcribed: Et se trouve à Paris, chez Cazin, rue des Maçons, no. 31.
pub cataloger notes: Translation of: De Ismeniae et Ismenes amoribus. | With a half-title. | Probably printed in Paris. | Title vignette | ""The Horace Howard Furness Memorial Gift of Horace Howard Furness, Jr. and Louise Brooks Winsor Furness"" sticker on verso facing half title page" | Library marginalia on first page of Advertisement, and back free endpaper
para:dedication: Begins: ""Madam, before I presumed to entreat your majesty\'s leave to grace with her august name the beginning of this slight performance, I read it not only to some of my countrymen well acquainted with the English language; but also to English gentlemen who seemed well pleased with it."" Signed, ""I am, Madam, your majesty\'s most humble and most devoted servant, Le Moine."
para:advertisement: Begins: ""This little romance, most commonly ascribed to Estathius, bishop of Thesselonica has been many times translated from Greek into French, Italian, and perhaps into English also; but that consideration has not deterred me from making this translation: as it is likely to be very different from any that may have preceded it; for tho\' this novel has many beauties in it, nevertheless by frequently reading it, I became sensible of their being disparaged by many things inconsistent with the principles of morality established among the Greeks: so that I have changed, omitted and added many passages in it. I have besides inserted here and there some verses from the best English poets, [...]"" ""I wish I might be permitted to name Mr. S******* whose friendship is an honour to me, as he is equally distinguished by his birth; his knowledge in every branch of literature, [...]"
title words:singular nouns: Novel | French | Esq | Valet de chambre | Majesty

Freret ... to the author, concerning the chronology of his work""." | Signatures: A² c⁴ a-b⁴ B-2Z⁴ 3A², ²B-P⁴ (²P4 blank). | Errata on verso of p. 363. | Engraved images labeled with J. Vander Gucht Sculp | With subscribers\' list.
para:preface: ""Ever since the first edition of The travels of Cyrus, the author has listen\'d with respect and deference to the judgments of the public; and as several specious objections have been made to the work, and many real faults discover\'d in it, his design in this preface is to give the best answer he can to the one, and to acquaint the reader with what he has done to correct the other."
para:dedication: ""My Lord, the most amiable virtues and brightest talents form\'d the character of that hero whose travels I relate: and to whom cou\'d I offer a picture of so fine a genius and so generous a mind but to a person of Your Lordship\'s taste?"
para:footnotes: Found throughout preface, main text, and letter.

para:preface: ""My readers will not call my veracity in question, when I assure them that I am ardently anxious for their approbation."
para:dedication: ""Sir, Although I am aware, that by electing for my humble productions a patronage so distinguished, I hazard the accusation or presumption, I rest confident that your candour will ascribe my temerity to the best possible motive."
para:footnotes: A single explanatory footnote located p. 13: ""The reader is requested to remember, that the essays which compose this first volume were written purposely for the Monthly museum, in which they originally appeared; and that they now stand precisely in the order, and nearly in the manner, in which they were first presented."

Halkett & Laing (2nd ed.); BM. | Vol. 2 is misdated 1776. | Vol. I: viii, 242 p.; v. 2: [4], 267, [5] p. (last page blank) | Advertisements on p. [2]-[4] at end of v. 2. | Library marginalia in pencil in volume 1: verso title page, dedication, and back fly paper; and volume 2, verso title page, first page of text, and back fly papers | Library bookplates on front fly paper of volume 1, front paste-down endpaper of volume 2
para:preface: ""Taking advantage of the prevailing rage for novels, the vehicles by which the most fatal poison is often conveyed to the heart, I send these volumes into the world, with the humane intention, perhaps presumptuous hope, of counteracting the effects of such productions, by inspiring my young Readers with juster sentiments, and a more correct taste, than what is usually acquired by perusing books of mere amusement."
para:dedication: ""Madam, to your Majesty, as the illustrious pattern of of every female virtue, and more particularly of those that add dignity even to the most exalted stations, I presume to dedicate a Work, intended for the improvement as well as amusement of youth."

author transcribed: By Mr. Treyssac de Vergy ... In two volumes.
title catalog: Henrietta, Countess Osenvor : a sentimental novel. In a series of letters to Lady Susannah Fitzroy. / By Mr. Treyssac de Vergy ... In two volumes.
title full: Henrietta, Countess Osenvor. A sentimental novel. In a series of letters to Lady Susannah Fitzroy, by Mr. Treyssac de Vergy, counsellor in the parliament of Paris. In two volumes.
pub transcribed: Printed for Harrison and Co. No. 18, Paternoster Row.
pub cataloger notes: Also issued as part of vol. 17 of: \'The novelist\'s magazine\', London, 1780-88. | Two volumes bound together, with continuous pagination. | The first leaf contains an advertisement. | Text printed in two columns | Library marginalia on back free endpaper
para:preface: ""Of my former works love and nature were the authors; they boldly held the pencil, and drew the pictures of the lovers."
para:dedication: ""Madam, were virtue, beauty, and the graces, to appear among us, they would assume your shape, your features--talk and feel as you do. I am, madam, your ladyship\'s most humble and obedient servant, Treyssac de Vergy"
para:advertisement: ""The candid and critical reader will find himself very little disposed to censure those peculiarities of stile which he cannot fail to observe in the following work, when he reflects that the whole was written in English by Monsieur de Vergy; and that it is now printed verbatim as originally published by the ingenious author, pursuant to the editor\'s invariable plan."
para:footnotes: Work contains a single footnote, located p. 13. Transcription: ""Like me, the reader must take this for a satire rather than for Mrs. Verman\'s real opinion: though seemingly in earnest, she had too much sense not to know the errors she commended. Had she painted them to her daughter under their true colours, she would not have acted the part she wanted to perform."

author transcribed: by Mr. Edward Ward.
title catalog: Miscellaneous writings, in verse and prose, both serious and comical : containing twenty one excellent poems upon very diverting subjects : also several pleasant letters upon various occasions, both in town and country : with merry observations and predictions upon every month, and every remarkable day throughout the year / by Mr. Edward Ward.
title full: Miscellaneous writings, in verse and prose, both serious and comical. Containing twenty one excellent poems upon very diverting subjects. Also several pleasant letters upon various occasions, both in town and country. With merry observations and predictions upon every month, and every remarkable day throughout the year. By Mr. Edward Ward. Vol. III. The third edition.
pub transcribed: Printed by W.D. and sold by A. Bettesworth at the Red Lyon in Pater-noster-Row.
pub cataloger notes: Printed after statement of responsibility on t.p.: Vol. III. The 5th ed. in book form of The London spy (1718) constitutes v. 1 of the author\'s miscellaneous writings. | The poems were originally published in 1706 under title: The third volume, consisting of poems on divers subjects / by the author of the London-spy. Cf. Troyer. | Signatures: A-Y8, 2A-B8 C4 H-O4 P1. | Various works contained in volume. The works are primarily poetry, but also includes theatrical dialogue, nonfiction, and letters. | University of Pennsylvania library bookplate and sticker on front paste down endpaper. Bookplate reads ""Gift of Julia Biddle" | Library marginalia on back free endpaper
para:preface: ""Never were times more difficult and dangerous for the sons of the muses to be sporting in, than at this present; for formerly they had no other enemies to dread but the by-blows of Apollo, called Criticks; who, because of their illegitimacy, having no just claim to the inheritance of Parnassus, [...]"
para:dedication: ""Sir, pardon me that I am bold to assure you, it is not the vanity of acquainting you I am become an author, or an ambition of perswading the world to believe I have any just pretence to shelter my mean performances, under the protection of so judicious a patron, that the motives which induce me to this freedom: [...]"" Signed: ""Your most humble, dutiful, and obedient servant, Edward Ward.""
para:to the reader: ""I have reason to suspect, from some clamours I have heard against the title of the first poem, which was call\'d, in the first edition, A journey to H---: or, A visit paid to the D-----, that \'tis a very wicked age we live in, since the very name of Hell and the Devil are such wonderful scare-crows to a parcel of puritanical fornicators, which, if they had been oftner put in mind of His infernal worship, and his dreadful dominions, might have been a means, for ought I know, of frighting \'em from a licentious and wicked life, into more honesty and vertue."

title catalog: A collection of the writings of Mr. Edward Ward. ... Vol. II.
title full: A collection of the writings of Mr. Edward Ward. Viz. I. The poet\'s ramble after riches: with reflections upon a country corporation: also the author\'s lamentation in the time of adversity. II. Sot\'s paradice: or, the humours of a derby ale-house. III. Ecclesia & Factie. A dialogue between bow-steeple dragon, and the exchange grasshopper. IV. Modern religion and antient loyalty. A dialogue. V. A walk to Islington: with a description of new Tunbridge-Wells, and Sadler\'s musick-house. VI. The insinuating bawd: or, the repenting harlot. VII. The revels of the gods: or, a ramble thro\' the heavens. VIII. Battle without bloodshed: or, martial discipline buffoon\'d by the city train bands. IX. O raree-show, o pretty show: or, the city feast. X. The cock-pit combat: or, the baiting of the tiger. XI. A hue and cry after the man midwife, who deliver\'d the land-bank of her money. XII. The Dutch guards farewel to England. XIII. A trip to Jamaica: with a true character of the people and island. XIV. A trip to New-England: with a character of the country and people, both English and Indians. XV. A frolick to horn-fair: with a walk from Cuckolds-point through Deptford and Greenwich. XVI. The dancing-school: with the adventures of the Easter holy-days. XVII. A step to stir-bitch-fair: with remarks upon the University of Cambridge. XVIII. The humours of a coffee-house. A comedy. XIX. The infallible predictor. XX. The rise and fall of Madam coming sir: or, an unfortunate slip from the tavern bar, into the surgeons powdering-tub. Vol II. The fifth edition.
pub transcribed: Printed for A. Bettesworth, at the Red Lion in Pater-noster-row,
pub cataloger notes: Page 75 incorrectly numbered 71; no. 233-234 omitted in the paging. | Title within double line border. | The first vol. of the author\'s miscellanies was the 5th ed. in book form of the London Spy (1718) For other vols. in the series, cf. Troyer. | Contains nonfiction chapters such as ""A trip to Jamaica"" and ""A trip to New-England." | University of Pennsylvania library bookplate and sticker in front paste down endpaper | Library marginalia on back paste down endpaper
para:to the reader: ""According to my promise in the London-spy, I have now presented you with a second volume of the same author\'s writings, wherein I dare engage the reader may and such variety of comick matter, as will at all times divert the spleen, or chase away all those terrible hobgoblins that attend the hippocondry."

para:to the reader: ""Unknown friend, who never saw\'st me in thy life, and perhaps never troublest thy self much about it, because there is no great matter to be got by the sight of a such a fellow as I am: be it known to thee, that neither am I desirous thou shoudst see my person, but that I have been inform\'d that some facetious gentlemen make themselves merry at the expence of an unhappy wretch, and describe me another sort of a monster than really I am."

Still, & gay, with sour grimace, & magisterial pride those canting sots the stoicks pain defied, yet fell beneath the burthen, nor t\'was tryed: none but my self did ere that pitch attain to sport with misery, & jest in pain"

para:to the reader: ""Unknown friend, who never saw\'st me in thy life, and perhaps never troublest thy self much about it, because there is no great matter to be got by the sight of such a fellow as I am: be it known to thee...."

title full: The eight volumes of letters writ by a Turkish spy, who liv\'d five and forty years undiscover\'d at Paris: giving an impartial account to the divan at Constantinople of the most remarkable transactions of Europe: and discovering several intrigues and secrets of the Christian courts, (especially of that of France) continued from the year 1637, to the year 1682. pub cataloger notes: Vol. 1: 2 l, ed., v. 2-8: 9th. ed. | Vol. 1 has both general and special t.-p.; v. 2-8 have special t.-p. only. | Authorities agree that the first part of the work, pub. in Paris 1684, was written by Marana. The remainder has been ascribed to different Englishmen, among them Dr. Robert Midgley and William Bradshaw. It is probable however that Midgley simply edited the English translation, made by Bradshaw, of the original Italian manuscript. cf. Gentleman\'s magazine, 1840-41; also, Dict. nat. biog., v. 6, p. 185; v. 37, p. 366. | University of Pennsylvania stickers and bookplate on front paste down endpaper in each volume (2 stickers and 1 bookplate in each) | Library-related marginalia in back free endpaper of each volume
para:preface: ""Besides the prefaces already affix\'d to each single volume of these letters, which contain particular answers to the objections and cavils of some, with solutions of the scruples and doubts made by others; as likewise critical explanations of passages, seeming obscure to all, in the English translation of our spy: it is thought necessary to prefix something more by way of general preface, not so much regarding the translation, as the seeming original abruptness and obscurity of our Arabian author himself in some places, with his frequent change of subjects [...]"
para:to the reader: ""I here offer you a book written by a Turk, whose matter is as instructive and delightful, as the manner of finding it was strange and surprizing."

title catalog: The new metamorphosis, or, pleasant transformation of the Golden ass of Lucius Apuleius of Medaura ; also the Golden spy, or, Magical wonders perform\'d by gold in the courts of Europe, in love and politicks, by its power on the favourite ladies in all ages : in twenty-five novels : altered and improved to the modern times and manners, exposing the secret follies and vices of maids, wives and widows, nuns, fryars and Jesuits, statesmen, and courtiers, &c. / written in Italian by Carlo Monte Socio, Fellow of the Academy of the Humoristi in Rome, and translated from the Vatican manuscripts ; to which is prefix\'d, the life of Lucius Apuleius. ... ; adorn\'d with new cuts.
title full: The new metamorphosis: or, pleasant transformation of the golden ass of Lucius Aouleius of Medaura. Also the golden spy: or, magical wonders perform\'d by gold in the courts of Europe, in love and politicks, by its power on the favourite ladies in all ages. In twenty-five novels. Altered and improved to the modern times and manners; exposing the secret follies and vices of maids, wives and widows; nuns, fyars and Jesuits; statesmen, and courtiers, &c. Written in Italian by Carlo Monte Socio, fellow of the academy of the humoristi in Rome, and translated from the Vatican manuscripts. To which is prefix\'d, the Life of Lucius Apuleius. In two volumes. Ardorn\'d with new cuts.
pub transcribed: Printed for Sam. Briscoe at the Bell-Savage on Ludgate-Hill.
pub cataloger notes: Published pseudonymously. By Charles Gildon. | Title pages printed in red and black ink. | Engraved plates by William Hogarth. | Racist commentary on state of literature in Preface, v.1: ""But if nothing but such sick dreams as The Arabian nights entertainments: The devil upon two sticks, &c will go do...Indeed England at this time seems the Africa of wit, where only monsters thrive and domineer, both on the theatte and in the press."
para:preface: ""This preface is not an idle complement to custom, or to insinuate my compliance with the importunities of friends in the publication of the following book; but there being a necessity of premising some few lines on the present performance, and the original or ground on which it is built."
para:intro: ""I send you, my good friend, with this billet, a copy of the manuscript taken from that of the memorable Seignior Fumoso de la Fantasia, of the delightful provice di Parnasso, fill\'d with the strange and wonderful fortunes which befel him, [...]"
para:footnotes: Located in Preface and on p. 145.

title catalog: The Algerine captive, or The life and adventures of Doctor Updike Underhill, six years a prisoner among the Algerines.
title full: The Algerine captive; or, the life and adventures of Doctor Updike Underhill: six years a prisoner among the Algerines. Volume I.
pub transcribed: By David Carlisle, Jun. and sold at his bookstore.
pub cataloger notes: Published anonymously. By Royall Tyler. Cf. Halkett & Laing (2nd ed.) | Errata: v. 2, p. [11]-[12] | Clipping inserted in book reads: ""1. I should like to say a word concerning David Evertt. He died in Mariett, O., in the early part of the last century, having gone there, if I have been correctly informed, to teach school. He had been one of that coterie of scholars who lived for a time in Walpole, N. H., and wrote for the New Hampshire Farmer, a newspaper established in that town by Isaiah Thomas. They were the first young men in this country to make literature a profession. Chief among them were Royall Tyler, later chief justice of Vermont, who wrote \'The Algerine Captive,\' the first American novel to be reprinted in London, and \'Joe\' Dennie (both of them originally of Boston), whose \'day sermons.\' published in the Farmer were read from New Hampshire to Georgia." | Bookplate reads: ""Ex Libris Edward Royall Tyler" | On title page reads: ""Published according to Act of Congress" | Library marginalia on back free endpaper | Individual epigraphs at the start of each chapter. Each chapter also has an argument summarizing the events of the chapter.
para:preface: Begins: ""One of the first observations, the author of the following sheets made, upon his return to his native country, after an absence of seven years, was the extreme avidity, with which books of mere amusement were purchased and perused by all ranks of his countrymen."
para:dedication: Reads: ""In Europe, dedications have their price; and the author oftener looks to the plenitude of the pockets, than the brains of his patron. The American author can hope but little pecuniary emolument from even the sale, and not any from the dedication of his work. To adorn his book with the name of some gentleman, of acknowledged merit, involves his whole interest, in a public address. With this view, will you, Sir, permit a lover of the muses, and a biographer of private life, to address to you (a poet and the biographer of a hero) a detail of those miseries of slavery, from which your public energies have principally conduced to liberate hundreds of our fellow citizens."" Signed: ""Updike Underhill. June 20, 1797.""
para:footnotes: Located throughout
title words:singular nouns: Captive | Life | Adventure | Doctor | Year | Prisoner | Volume

author transcribed: Tr. from the French, by W. Hooper, M. A.
title catalog: Memoirs of the year two thousand five hundred ... Tr. from the French, by W. Hooper, M. A.
title full: Memoirs of the year two thousand five hundred. Translated from the French, by W. Hooper, M.A.
pub transcribed: Printed by Thomas Dobson, at the stone-house, No 41, South Second-Street.
pub cataloger notes: Translation of: L\'an deux mille quatre cent quarante.           | Translated by William Hooper. | Attributed to Louis-Sebastien Mercier in Barbier, A.A. Ouvrages anonymes.           | Library marginalia on title page and advertisement.
para:dedication: ""August and venerable year! thou who art to bring felicity upon the earth! thou, alas! that I have only in a dream beheld, when thou shalt rise from out of the bosom of eternity, thy sun shall enlighten them who will tread upon my ashes, and upon those of thirt generations, successively cut off, and plunged in the profound abyss of death."
para:advertisement: Reads: ""The title of this work in the original is The Year Two Thousand Four Hundred and Forty; but as there appears no reason for fixing it to any particular year, we have for the sake of a round number, called it The Year Two Thousand Five Hundred. It may be proper to add, that this is the only alteration made by the translator. Though the scene of this narrative lies in Paris, yet the reflections in general may be applied, by changing the names of places and persons, to almost all the capital cities of Europe. Who the author of this work is, we will not pretend to determine; perhaps the reader will be satisfied with finding the he is a man of sense, of taste, and learning, of a lively imagination, a strong spirit of liberty, and, what is worth them all, a warm benevolence of heart."
para:intro: ""That all should be well is the wish of the philosopher. By that term, which doubtless has been abused, I mean that sagacious and virtuous being, who desires the general happiness, in consequence of those determinate ideas of order and harmony that he entertains."
para:footnotes: true
title words:singular nouns: Memoir | Year | Two thousand five hundred | French | M.A.

para:preface: Begins: ""The author thinks it very probable that the judicious reader will discern many defects and inequalities in the work before him; she is desirous to bespeak his candour and allowance for them, by relating the circumstances that gave birth to it.""
para:dedication: Fictional dedicatee. Begins: ""In the course of my obeservations upon the various characters which both nature and art have exhibited to my view, I have frequently met with persons of your name and family, and have remarked with surprise, and even admiration, upon the consequence they have obtained, and the advantages they have derived from the display of their own self-importance.""

para:preface: Begins: ""The author thinks it very probable that the judicious reader will discern many defects and inequalities in the work before him; she is desirous to bespeak his candour and allowance for them, by relating the circumstances that gave birth to it.""
para:dedication: Fictional dedicatee. Begins: ""In the course of my obeservations upon the various characters which both nature and art have exhibited to my view, I have frequently met with persons of your name and family, and have remarked with surprise, and even admiration, upon the consequence they have obtained, and the advantages they have derived from the display of their own self-importance.""

pub transcribed: Printed for T. Hookham, New Bond Street.
pub cataloger notes: Dedication signed: ****** | Bookseller\'s advertisements: v. 1, [2] p. at end. | Bookplates on front paste-down endpaper and front free endpaper in all three volumes: one reads, ""Opes parit industria"" and one is a University of Pennsylvania bookplate." | Library marginalia on recto and verso of dedication and recto and verso of first page of text in v.2 and v.3.; also on back free endpaper in all three volumes
para:dedication: ""Madam, It may, perhaps, appear extraordinary, that a tale invented by some years ago, and verbally repeated to you about three winters past; when the study of the day was over, and needlework supplied the place of books, music, and drawing; and you and I were agreeably seated together, and that, although your fingers were employed, your mind, ever desirous to be amused by instruction, I, at your solicitation, called to my remembrance the fable of Captain and Miss Rivers: [...]"

title catalog: The Man of benevolence.
title full: The man of benevolence.
pub transcribed: Printed for the author, and sold by Hughes and Walsh, Inner Temple Lane; Morgan, Ludgate Hill; Buckland, Pater-noster Row; and Raithby, St. Michael\'s Alley, Cornhill.
para:preface: Begins: ""The man who deprives another of his property is amenable to the laws of his country, but he who robs us of our time, by affecting to instruct or to amuse us, is not amenable to any laws, nor is he subject to any punishment."
para:dedication: Begins: ""With the false pride natural to an author, I wished to discover some titled patron, to whom I might dedicate the following performance; but I considered that titles reflect no lustre, save only on their immediate possessors, and that the vices of the greatest men frequently escape from the glitter of pomp, and, by reaching the ears of the multitude, put to confusion the writer who has extolled their imaginary virtues."

Evans, printer, (41) Long-Lane, London." | Library-related marginalia located back fly paper, v.1-3. | Ink marginalia slightly visible beneath front paste-down endpaper, v.2. | Published in London - Holborn is a major street and area in central London.
para:preface: ""Whether the ensuing pages were originally designed for public view, or merely to amuse the leisure hours of my departed friend, is more than I can undertake to answer; but as every thing is, or should be valuable, which a friend bequeaths, have preserved the following letters, which were left with other things as a memorandum of friendship and regard.""

title full: The niece; or the history of Sukey Thornby. A novel. In three volumes. Vol. I. By Mrs. P. Gibbes, author of the history of Lady Louisa Stroud.
pub transcribed: Printed for F. Noble, at his circulating library, No. 324, Holborn
pub cataloger notes: Advertisements: v. 1, final page; v. 3, [5] p. at end. | University of Pennsylvania library sticker and bookplate on front paste down endpaper in all three volumes | Library marginalia on first page of text and back free and paste down endpaper in both volumes
para:preface: ""It is very unusual to prefix any kind of introduction to works of this sort; but I must beg leave to observe, that this novel, being written on a plan entirely new, (to avoid the many repetitions of \'said he,\' and \'said she,\' which so frequently grate the ear) I have thrown the several incidents by way of dialogue, and it would not be of any impropriety if it were called \'a dramatic novel.\'"

"

para:to the reader: Begins: ""Ladies, permit me to solicit your kind patronage and protection of the following sheets, throughout which, I have no doubt, many errors may be discovered; yet I am encouraged to hope that your goodness will attribute them wholly to juvenile inexperience; for surely not any of my fair readers will imagine, that a person at the age of seventeen can be capable of conducting her first essay in the same correct stile with those who have studied for several years."" Signed: ""Ladies, with the utmost respect, your much obliged and devoted humble servant, Eliz. Todd. No. 21, Queen Street, Westminster"

para:dedication: Begins ""Sir, at the same time that I solicit your protection of Agnes de Courci, I acknowledge myself to be impelled thereto, by the two grand motives, which the world have long been pleased to ascribe to dedicators in general, notwithstanding a vast deal of fine writing to prove the contrary; namely, vanity and self-interest: but to these I beg leave to add a third, more predominant, even in a female breast, than either; which is gratitude."" Signed: ""Sir, your gratefully devoted humblr servant, The author."

para:dedication: ""Madam, your ladyship\'s known goodness gives my presumption the hopes of a pardon, for prefixing to this slight work the name of a lady, whose accurate judgement has long been the glory of her own sex, and the wonder of ours: especially since it arose from a vanity, to which your indulgence, on the first perusal of it, gave birth.""

para:advertisement: Begins ""A propensity to gaming having of late given strong encouragement to usury, and the fortunes of several distinguished families been irreparably hurt by that prevailing infatuation, the authoress presumes to hope she may stand excused to delineate the fatal consequences in their most glaring colours."

title catalog: Warbeck : a pathetic tale, in two volumes.
title full: Warbeck: a pathetic tale. In two volumes. Vol. I.
pub transcribed: Printed for William Lane, Leadenhall-Street.
pub cataloger notes: ""Written in French, by M. D\'Arnaud""--Pref." | Translated by Sophia Lee | Library marginalia located verso front free endpaper and recto back free endpaper of both volumes
para:preface: Begins: ""The following work was written in French, by M. D\'Arnaud, an author justly celebrated for his profound knowledge of the human heart, which he has displayed in a number of pathetic pieces, as well for the closet as the stage.""
para:intro: Begins: ""Soon after the accession of Henry VII. to the throne of England, a report was spread of that monarch\'s intention to take away the life of the young Earl of Warwick, son of the Duke of Clarence, and the only surviving male of the House of York, who was at that time a prisoner in the Tower of London. Richard Simon, a priest of Oxford, a man of some subtlety, and more rashness, conceived, from this circumstance, the bold project of drawing a young man, named Lambert Simnel, from the shop of a baker, and persuading him to personate the Earl of Warwick.""
para:footnotes: Located in Preface.

Literary Digest International Book Review, IV, p. 381-382." | Library marginalia on recto of dedication, full title page of volume 1, and back free and paste-down endpapers
para:preface: ""I am happy that in presenting the following letters to the public, I am not exhibiting scenes, or communicating opinions, that can wound delicacy, or pervert sentiment."
para:dedication: ""Not more honoured for her dignity, than revered for her piety, and beloved for her virtues; the following letters are, with all humility, inscribed by the editor."
para:footnotes: Footnotes throughout both paratext and text itself; in the Preface, reference is made to Goethe\'s The Sorrows of Young Werter, and some excerpts from that are quoted. On p. 43-45, a poem appears in an extended footnote.

para:advertisement: ""I am obliged to fortune for the papers I now offer to the public. I little imagined, when I bought an old bureau, that I was purchasing a work of fancy; for such I must suspect this little work to be, though it contains many incidents that bear so much the appearance of reality, they they may claim some share of our belief."" Credited to ""The author of David Simple."
para:intro: ""Your ladyship had little compassion either either on yourself or me, when you desired me to write you an exact account of every circumstance of my life, and even of my thoughts, or you did not consider the long detail into which this lead me; a detail tedious for you to read, and difficult for me to write."

para:advertisement: Begins: ""Considering the partiality that is entertained for novels in this country, it is much to be regretted that the generality of them are not written in a style and manner sufficiently excellent to justify so established a prejudice in their favour;---on the contrary, in very many instances, we find the characters are unnatural, the plot improbable, and the language flimsy and unmeaning."

Prebendary of York &c. &c." | Black square printed onto p. 67-8, v.1. | Library marginalia on verso of third to last leaf, v.1, v.3, v.5 | Narrative is in French from p.123-128, v.1. | Blank page on p.152 of v.2. | Green bookmark between p.186 and 187. | ""Slawkenbergius\'s Tale"" from p.52-53, v.3." | ""Ode"" on p.110 of v.3." | Bookmark between p.94 and p.95, v.5 | Illustration of ""flourish"" on p.108" | Chapter XXXVIII and XXXIX are blank, v.6 | Frontispieces to v.1-3 by Hogarth.
para:dedication: ""Sir, never poor wight of a dedicator had less hopes from his dedication, than I have from this of mine; for it is written in a bye corner of the kingdom, and in a retir\'d thatch\'d house, where I live in constant endeavour to fence against the infirmities of ill health, and other evils of life, by mirth; being firmly persuaded that every time a man smiles,-- but much more so, when he laughs, it adds something to this fragment of life."

edition trans: Second edition. To which is added, Harriet: or, the vicar\'s tale
pub transcribed: For J. Forbes, C. Elliot and and T. Kay, P. M\'Queen, T. and J. Egerton, Shepperdson and Reynold, C. Stalker; C. Rann, Oxford; Todd, Tork; and C. Elliot, Edinburg.
pub cataloger notes: In the publication statement on title page, those after London have the name of the city printed after the name of the bookseller. | Name of author supplied from ESTC:  ""author of Maria=George Monck Berkeley""." | Vol. 2 is in two parts:  the first includes the conclusion of ""Heloise, or, The siege of Rhodes"", and a bookseller\'s advertisement on p. 139; the second includes ""Harriet, or, The vicar\'s tale"", with special title page, and separate pagination and signatures." | Dedicated to ""Mrs. Ward""." | University of Pennsylvania sticker on front pastedown endpaperof both volumes | Library marginalia on v.1 dedication and back free endpaperof both volumes | Book advertisement slip in v.2 including bibliographic and physical information, as well as a description of the books contents. E.g.: ""A popular gothic romance by the great-grandson of the philosopher. Set in the days of chivalry and featuring a mad heroine and a hermit, the novel was several times published or reissued but is now scarce in any edition...The novel received moderate, if not ecstatic praise from contemporary reviewers. Christopher Lake Moody wrote in the Monthly Review: \'The practice of virtue is here inculcated, and the truth of imitation preserved. The scene is laid in the days of chivalry, and the adventures are such as might happen in fuedal times. The incidents are contrived with art; the diction is elegant, yet natural; the sentiments are always interesting, often pathetic, and sometimes sublime.\' (MR 79:84 (July 1788)."
para:preface: Begins: ""Although the candour with which the author\'s former attempts have been received, has served, in some degree, to dissipate those apprehensions, inseparable from the breast of him who presumes to attract the public attention; yet (he flatters himself) it has by no means lessened his anxiety to pleaase."" Later: ""As this is the last time the author will ever expose himself to criticism, (in the character of a novelist) he has been particularly assiduous to merit a continuation of that indulgence he has hitherto experienced."" Dated: ""Oxford, Dec. 21, 1787."
para:dedication: Transcription: ""To the honorable Mrs. Ward, are these volumes respectfully inscribed, by her obliged and very obedient humble servant, the author."
para:advertisement: Transcription: ""The author cannot suffer a second edition to appear, without expressing the gratitude he feels for teh very flattering marks of approbation with which the siege of Rhodes has been honored by the public."" Dated: ""Inner Temple, April 2, 1788."
para:footnotes: In the preface on p. ii, vii, viii.
epigraph source transcribed: Proeme to the Fairy Queen | Spencer
title words:other works: Maria: or, the generous rustic | Harriet: or, the vicar\'s tale

pub transcribed: Printed for, and sold by the author; and G. G. J. & J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row, London.
pub notes: ""Price four shillings. [Entered in Stationers Hall.]"" printed beneath publication information."
pub cataloger notes: Subscriber\'s list: p. [xvi]-xxvi. | Library marginalia on back free endpaper | Marbled front and back free and paste down endpapers | ""The Edwin Forrest Home"" stickers on front paste down endpaper; one has the blanks filled out, indicating: ""Section \'9\'"" and ""Shelf \'3\'"" and the other reads ""Duplicate" | Fold out illustration after pg. 206. of a ship at sea, with the heading ""Bahama Banks, 1767"". The illustration is captioned with a quote from Job Ch. 33, Verse 14-16 and 29-30." | Apparent printing error. Pg. 181 located before pg. 207, immediately following foldout illustration. | P. 290-294 contain an extended poem entitled ""Miscellaneous Verses"", seemingly written by Equiano"
para:dedication: Begins: ""My lords and gentlemen, Permit me, with the greatest deference and respect, to lay at your feet the following genuine narrative; the chief design of which is to excite in your august assemblies a sense of compassionf for the miseries which the slave-trade has entailed on my unfortunate countrymen."" Signed, ""I am, my lords and gentlemen, your most obedient, and devoted servant, Olaudah Equiano, or Gustavus Vassa. June 1792."
para:to the reader: Begins, ""An invidious falsehood having appeared in the Oracle of the 25th, and the star of the 27th of April 1752, with a view to hurt my character, and to discredit and prevent the sale of my narrative, asserting, that I was born in the Danish island of Santa Cruz, in the West Indies, it is necessary that, in this edition, I should take notice thereof, and it is only needful for me to appeal to those numerous and respectable persons of character who knew me when I first arrived in England, and could speak no language but that of Africa"". This section goes on to print a series of letters and recommendations from various people verifying Equiano\'s narrative."
para:footnotes: Descriptive/explanatory footnotes appear frequently throughout text, including in the paratext (in To the Reader)

author transcribed: written by himself, and translated from the German ...
title catalog: The life of Frederick, Baron Trenck / written by himself, and translated from the German ...
title full: The life of Frederick, Baron Trenck. Written by himself, and translated from the German. Vol. I.
pub transcribed: Printed for J. Murray, No. 32, Fleet-Street.
pub cataloger notes: Signatures: v. 1: A-I12, K6, L2; v. 2: A-I12. | Errata slip pasted to sig. L2r, v. 1. | Publisher\'s advertisements: v.1, p.[1] at end; v.2, p.[4]-[5] at end. | Frontispiece, portrait of Frederic Baron Trenck, ""loaded with chains in his dungeon at Madgeburg"" (v.1)." | Bookplate on front pastedown endpaper, v.1-2. Ornate seal, ""nihil ultra vires"" written on it. Beneath reads: ""Essex Henry Bond"
para:preface: Begins: ""I have little to say of this work; it speaks for itself, and needs no other explanation. It is not a romance, but a history: it is the narrative of real events that passed in the presence of witnesses still alive, and the author, who is at the same time the hero of the story, consents to abide by the judgement of an equitable publick."" At end reads: ""Written at my house at Schwebach, in the month of June, 1786, in the sixtieth year of my life.""
para:dedication: Begins: ""Sire, this singular book, an appeal to the inhabitants of the earth, was not intended for publication till after my death; that is to say, till the time when the writer would no longer have any thing to fear, and it would be possible to speak truth with impunity."" Signed: ""Sire, your majesty\'s most faithful subject, Trenck.""
para:advertisement: Begins: ""The translator has hasted to give this work to his countrymen, convinced that the publick curiosity will be highly gratified by the perusal of so extraordinary a history: a history, which though true, so nearly resembles the flights of fancy, that it seems to have destroyed the established boundaires and criterion of fiction and facts.""
para:footnotes: Explanatory footnotes throughout Explanation of plate and main text.

para:preface: Being in company, some months ago, with several of the learned authoresses of the adventures of inanimate beings, such as peg-tops, pincushions, kites, &c. and likewise the compilers of memoirs of rather more rational (although dumb) animals; and hearing the great praise bestowed on such productions; it naturally occurred to me, that, under the title of ""The adventures of a pin,"" as much amusement and instruction might be conveyed, (to those who desire it), as either of my predecessors can boast of having circulated."

G. Lewis. --- London, June 21, 1808.

para:preface: The name of Don Sebastian immediately recals to every historical reader, a character, which youth, faults, virtues, and misfortunes, have rendered highly interesting: I selected such a one for my hero, from the wish of shewing how ""sweet are the uses of adversity."
para:intro: Never has the pen of history had to record a more affecting event, than that which bore the house of Braganza to another hemisphere: animated by a noble disdain of submitting to foreign despotism, and bravely placing his country, not in the land of Portugal, but in the hearts of her people, the Prince Regent conquered in adversity, and triumphed even at the moment of despair.
para:footnotes: Pg. 49 v.3: To lessen the number of agents necessary for the plan of this romance, the author has ventured occasional violations of the chronology[...]

para:preface: Transcription : Before this work is perused by the reader, I beg to declare, that it makes no pretensions to any praise, but that of inoffensiveness: It was written at different times, merely as an amusement for the languid hours, which followed long and repeated fits of sickness; and is not, therefore, brought forward now, as a candidate for literary honors.
para:dedication: Transcription : Sir, when I reflect upon the genius, taste, and judgment of him, to whom I would dedicate this work, I become inclined to withhold from myself, so great a pleasure[...]

para:dedication: Transcription : Though personally unknown to you, dear sir, I venture to inscribe even such a work as this, with your respected name, because I have no other way of expressing my gratitude, or of publicly acknowledging, that to your skill and benevolence, under God, I am indebted for the life of a distant and most dear brother.
para:to the reader: Transcription : If the reader of the following work happen to have read its predecessor, ""The Village of Mariendorpt,"" it may be necessary to apprize him that the resemblance he may possibly detect between some features of the two stories, is not accidental."

title catalog: The old English baron : a Gothic story.
title full: The old English baron: a gothic story. By Clara Reeve. A new edition.
pub transcribed: Printed for Charles Dilly,
pub cataloger notes: Dedication signed: Clara Reeve. | Originally published under title: The champion of virtue. | Bookplate : The Fales Collection --- New York University | Notes throughout the book about condition of manuscript : pg. 30, ""Here follows an interval of four years, as by the manuscript; and this omission seems intended by the writer. What follows is in a different hand, and the character is more modern."" Pg. 39, ""From this place the characters in the manuscript are effaced by time and damp. Here and there some sentences are illegible [...]""; Pg. 45, ""Another pause ensues here [...] Here the manuscript is not legible for several pages. There is mention, about this time, of the death of the Lady Fitz-Owen; but not the cause."" Pg. 46, ""The manuscript is again defaced for many leaves; at length the letters become more legible, and the remainder of it is quite perfect." | Preface is a defense of fiction and novels : [...] This story is of the literary offspring of the Castle of Otranto, written written upon the same plan, with a design to unite [...] the ancient romance and modern novel [...] a man shall admire and almost adore the epic poems of the ancients, and yet despise [...] romances, which are only epics in prose. [...] The business of romance is, first, to excite the attention; and secondly, to direct it to some useful, or at least innocent end: happy the writer who attains both these points, like Richardson!
para:preface: As this story is of a new species which, though not new, is out of the common track, it has been thought necessary to point out some circumstances to the reader, which will elucidate the design, and, it is hoped, will induce him to form a favorable, as well as a right judgement of the work before him.
para:dedication: Madam, --- This new edition of the English Baron begs permission to acknowledge your patronage and protection, of which it has long felt the advantages.

para:advertisement: So long a period having elapsed since the speedy publication of The Wanderings of Warwick in two volumes was announced, the publisher conceives he should be waiting in that respect which he owes to the public, were he now silently to publish the work in one, without stating his own exculpation, that both the delay, and the promising it in two volumes, are imputable solely to the author--to whom he leaves the task of justifying her own conduct.

para:preface: Transcription : Courteous reader, I think I have pretty generally observed that authors of celebrity seldom begin, continue, or end a work without the two popular words ""courteous reader."
para:dedication: Transcription : To the most illuminated and enormous Queen Clumdalca! Chief character in the tragical scene of thumb; patentee of the pendantick practice of scholastic verbosity; prime administrator of the homonymous court of literature; patroness of the curious society of pathetical poetasters; and czarina of all the scribbling states on Jabber Ocean!!!
para:intro: Transcription : Courteous readers all! I shall not detain you with an account of the causes which induced me to write upon so many sheets of paper, or of what is contained in them: we are somewhat told ""errors, like straws, upon the surface flow---He who would search for pearls must dive below."
para:footnotes: Pg. 155 : It must be evident to every one of ""classical education common discernment,"" that Lucifer, the silver winged post-boy of the Sun, is the brightest morning star introduced above, and supposed to be waltzing with the Aurora.

author transcribed: Translated from the German of Mr. Gessner.
title catalog: Daphnis: A Poetrical, Paftoral Novel. Translated from the German of Mr. Gessner.
title full: Daphnis: A Poetrical, Paftoral Novel. Tranflated from the German of Mr. Gessner, The celebrated Author of the Death of Abel. By an English Gentleman, who refided feveral Years at Hamburgh. To which is prefixed, a Prefatory Difcourfe on the Origin and Ufe of Pastoral Poetry.
pub transcribed: Sold by J. Dodsley, in Pall-mall; T. Cadell, in the Strand; W. Owen, Temple-Bar; G. Kearsley, Ludgate-ftreet; J. Wilkie and W. Nicoll, in St. Paul\'s Church-yard; and W. Davenhill, at the Royal Exchange.
para:preface: Begins: "Germany has of late made a confpicuous figure in the republick of letters. Animated by Britifh alliances, and Britifh examples, fhe nobly emulates her kindred nation both in literary and military fame. For the truth of this we may appeal to her illuftrious heroes and undaunted troops, who fo much diftinguifhed themfelves in the laft war, and likewife to the many recent works of learning which do fo much honour to that nation, and whofe authors have fully refcued it from the imputation of want of tafte and genius, with which it has been fo long, and fo often unjuftly reproached."
para:dedication: Reads: "Sir, Your defcent from the moft illuftrious Princes of Great Britain and Germany, and the high dignitiy of your title, which is truly paftoral, will, it is humbly hoped, in fome meafure justify the propriety, and apologize for the prefumption of dedicating This Discourse on the Origin and Use of Pastoral Poetry, and this Translation of Daphnis from the German into the English Language, to your Royal Highnefs. Pleafe to receive, Sir, from the tender hands of orphan innocence, this little wreath of flowers, with which the Mufes here prefent you; and may poetry, with the other polite arts, prove fome of the agreeable entertainments and fofter amufements of your younger years. The celebrated Mr. Gessner has truly and juftly obferved, that poetry has always been in the retinue of religion, and has greatly promoted her facred caufe; that it is a avery powerful and delightful method of teaching the leffons of morality; that it improves and refines the underftanding, and excites mankind to every laudable, worthy, and noble action. Small, therefore, as this poetical volume may appear to be, yet as it is of a moral tendency, there is fome pleafing encouragement to hope that it may not be altogether unacceptable to your Royal Highnefs. Formed by the wife precepts and illuftrious examples of your Royal Parents, that you may long inherit all their virtues, and fhare their glorious renown, fhall be the daily prayer of, Sir, Your Royal Highnefs\'s moft obedient, and moft humble Servant, Charlotte Butler."

para:preface: "It is a maxim, with some critics, that Poetry is not to be translated. I am afraid, also, however loth we translators may be to subscribe to it, that there is more truth in this assertion than will be readily acknowleged. This is indubitably certain, that the most arduous task of a tranflator is to convey that happy combination of stile and sentiment, in which poesy consists, from one language to another."

pub transcribed: Printed for William Lane at the Minerva Press, Leadenhall-Street.
pub cataloger notes: On the full title pages of Vol. I and Vol. II, there are stamps that read "Redwood Library, Newport, RI, Duplicate Sold." The stamp is in blue; beneath both blue stamps are stamps in red, also from the Redwood Library.
para:dedication: The dedication reads: Gentlemen, That the hasty production of two short months, the greater part of which has been engaged in the humble pursuits of my avocation, should afford leisure to the author to produce a work, in all points so correspondently just as to meet that encouragement it otherwise might have done, the candid judicious reader will allow could scarcely be expected; the idea that gave rise to the opinions thus humbly brought into notice, are the consequence of some little observation, and much feeling resulting purely from the interest I have in the prosperity of the state, and the happiness and independence of the commercial world, forming, as it does, so very efficient a part of it; if the original idea is rather slightly pursued, and extraneous matter introduced, in order to render it somewhat more agreeable to the younger part of my readers, and to make it, at the same time, interesting to the lovely and amiable part of the other sex, I trust the desire of so doing will excuse the deviation, it being intended only faintly to pourtray to the intelligent reader what has eventually carried misery into many truly respectable families."
para:to the reader: Written in verse

title catalog: The labyrinths of life : a novel / by the author of Excessive sensibility, and Fatal follies : in four volumes.

title half: The labyrinths of life. Vol. I.
pub transcribed: Printed by G.G.J. and J. Robinson, Pater-Noster-Row,
pub cataloger notes: Published anonymously.  Attributed to Harriet Pigott.  Cf. Halkett & Laing (2nd ed.)  Also attributed to Mrs. Thomson.  Cf. Allibone, S.A.  Critical dictionary of English literature. | Advertisements: v. 4, last 2 leaves.
para:dedication: "Madam, Though the practice of dedicating books to distinguished characters has, like other things, been perverted in some instances to low purposes, yet in its origin it was neither unnatural nor unuseful [...] The author was animated with the idea that at least one good judge, whom he was ambitious to please, would read what he wrote: and, in writing, the same idea operated as a monitor, that no sentiment or expression should be suffered to escape the pen of the author, that the judgement, the taste, or the virtue of the party addressed might be ready to condemn. It is on these principles that I have presumed to address to your Grace The Labyrinths of Life, intended to shew, that amidst all the fluctuations of human affairs, however surprising, there is, sooner or latter, a reward for patient and preserving probity and honour."

pub cataloger notes: Author (text); claim type: generic/descriptive; location: p. 3, Vol. I.; transcription of claim: "Since I am writing her history, then, I will begin with a description of her person, concerning which, your Ladyship, like a true woman, is particularly inquisitive; and here being a woman likewise..." This authorship claim introduces a female gender claim, which isn\'t present in the claim on the title page. | Library of the University of Pennsylvania  and Godfrey F. Singer bookplate on front pastedown of Vol. I and Vol. II.
para:to the reader: "The writer of the following sheets was prevailed upon to make them public, by the Lady to whom they are addressed, who thought the conduct of Eliza, in some of the most trying circumstances of life, would afford a useful lesson for her sex, and whose amiable character deserved to be drawn from obscurity. Those who read only for amusement, will find themselves disappointed; if, in this little performance, they expect to meet with any of those surprising turns of fortune, so easily created by the imagination, but which the judgement can never realize. The History of Eliza is a narrative of facts, which gives the relator no claim to the merit of invention; if the public is pleased with her manner of relating them, her expectations will be more than answered."

pub transcribed: Printed by Henry Saunders, at the corner of Christ-Church-Lane, in High-Street,
para:dedication: "My lord, permit me to request your acceptance of these memoirs, the first essay of my pen, and, at the same time, to pardon my presumption, in offering to your protection and patronage a work, the greatest merit of which must be your approbation.

British fiction, 1750-1770, 1325, Notes, for reference to this work. | Bookplate - "Nec volenti nec volenti."  Front pastedown.  Edward Westby, Esq. | An unlabeled author\'s note appears at the end of the last letter of Vol. II. It is written in italics. It reads: "The two friends left off writing, because lady Balfour went to visit her friend, along with Mrs. Darby, and staid there a considerable time."
para:footnotes: On p. 286 of Vol. I, a footnote is denoted with an asterisk; it clarifies information on the world external to the novel ("A Carthusian monastery, which practices the greatest austerities.")

title catalog: The heroick princes, or, The conscious lovers ... : with eight curious copper plates.
title full: The heroick princes: or, The conscious lovers. Containing, I. A series of most surprising adventures of the magnanimous Prince Formidaur and Prince Florian. II. Formidaur falls in love with Zelinda. III. Believes her to be his own sister, and yet continues his suit to her. IV. The agonies thro\' love and despair he is alternately thrown into upon that account, and the consequences of his passion. V. Florian marries Fidalme, whom he supposes to be his father\'s daughter by a second wife; was infinitely fond of her. VI. Kills her afterwards in disguise in a duel. VII. The dreadful misfortunes which followed his doing so. VIII. Several strange accidents and extraordinary events, which attended the princes after this, not to be paralell\'d in history. IX. By a sudden and amazing turn of fortune, both the princes master all difficulties, and become very happy at last. With eight curious copper-plates. The third edition. [Price one shilling.]
pub transcribed: Printed for I. Pottinger, in Pater-Noster-Row.
pub cataloger notes: Illustrations on p. 32 (caption: Carilda going to stab Frontel in his sleep.), p. 40 (caption: Florian finds it to be his wife Fidalme whom he had slain in single combat.), p. 70 (caption: Formidaur is introduced to Isdigerdes his grandfather tho\' unknown.), p. 84 (caption: Formidaur overthrows Pantories a monstrous Tartar in single combat.), p. 89 (caption: Florian comes in womens cloaths to deliver Formidaur from prison.), p. 101 (caption: Formidaur going to release Florian whom he had left imprison\'d in his stead, finds a headless body.), p. 105 (caption: Formidaur going to stab the Satrapa of Gore is witheld by Florian, whom he thought beheaded.). | Pages of text numbered independently of illustrations, suggesting the illustrations were printed as inserts. Page numbers that appear on top of illustrations match either the verso of the previous page or the recto of the following page. | One illustration appears to be missing: the title page advertises eight copper-plates, but only seven illustrations are printed in this work.

title catalog: The adventures of a hackney coach.
title full: The adventures of a hackney coach. The third edition corrected.
pub transcribed: Printed for G. Kearsley, No 46, Fleet-Street.
pub cataloger notes: Sometimes attributed to M. Pelham [i.e. Dorothy Kilner].  Cf. Halkett & Laing (2nd ed., suppl.); Block, A. Engl. novel, p. 128. | Vol. 2 has no edition statement. | Issued in 1 volume. | Vol. 1: 6, [2], iv, 150, [2] p. (last page blank); v. 2, vi, [7]-168 p. | Advertisements on p. [1] at end of v. 1 and last page of v. 2.
para:preface: First lines read: "When I sat down to collect the particulars of the following work, the uncommon success of which stimulates me to a continuation, which will be ready for my numerous readers in a short time, I examined every character introduced with the equitable eye of justice. When I exhibited them to the inspection of those powerful members of society, genius and friendship, I was led to think the colouring beautiful, and the execution every way characteristically just."
para:dedication: Date appears at the bottom of the dedication: Lond. March 11, 1781.
para:advertisement: First lines read: "I cannot publish this volume without presenting the warmest effusions of gratitude to the readers of my first volume. In an age where the harvest of literature is all got in, and such a number of leasers croud over the field as at present exist, it is next to a miracle to pick up any thing worthy attention. ----- Some gentlemen reviewers wantonly cut a hole in my sack it is true; and endeavoured to rob me of property; but what could I expect, when I had the partisans of a host of foes to combat with?"
para:footnotes: Footnotes that elaborate upon or explain a fictional element of the novel can be found in Vol. I on p. 34, 74, 116, 126, 127 and in Vol. II on p. 62.

Singer memorial presented by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Singer" | In addition to the main running title, the work also includes volume and letter number as a running title, eg "Vol. [number]" (verso) "Let. para:preface: The first sentences read: "The editor of he following letters takes leave to observe, that he has now, in this publication, completed the plan, that was the object of his wishes, rather than of his hopes, to accomplish. How such remarkable collections of private letters fell into his hands, he hopes the reader will not think it very necessary to enquire."
para:to the reader: This address to the public contains an account of the defense Mr. Faulkner presented in a legal battle between the bookseller Mr. Faulkner and Samuel Richardson. The essay is printed in such a way that "Mr. Faulkner\'s defense." is printed as an insert alongside the larger "Genuine history of the transaction"

title catalog: Canterbury tales ...
title full: Canterbury tales for the year 1797. By Harriet Lee.
title half: Canterbury tales. Volume the second.
pub transcribed: Printed for G. G. and J. Robinson, Paternoster-Row.
pub cataloger notes: Vol. 1 has title: Canterbury tales for the year 1797. | Vol. 2 by Sophia Lee, 1798; vol. 3 by Sophia and Harriet Lee, 1799. | Vol. 5: London, Printed for G. Wilkie and J. Robinson [etc.] 1805. | Vol. I includes The traveller\'s tale. Montford [p. 1]; The poet\'s tale. Arundel. [p. 41]; The frenchman\'s tale. Constance [p. 191]; The old woman\'s tale. Lothaire: a legend [p. 331]. Vol. II includes The young lady\'s tale. The two Emilys [p. 1]. Vol. III includes The officer\'s tale. William Cavendish [p. 1]; The clergyman\'s tale. Henry [p. 195]. | Each tale begins with an epigraph. In Vol. I, The traveller\'s tale and The poet\'s tale both have epigraphs attributed to Shakespeare; The frenchman\'s tale has an unattributed epigraph; and The old woman\'s tale has an epigraph attributed to Shirley. In Vol. II, The young lady\'s tale has an unattributed epigraph. In Vol. III, The officer\'s tale has an epigraph attributed to Pope\'s Homer, and The clergyman\'s tale has an epigraph attributed to Shakespeare. | The officer\'s tale in Vol. III is initialled "H.L." on p. 194. | Running titles on the verso sides of pages remain constant: "Canterbury tales." The running title on the recto side reflects the current tale (for example, "The traveller\'s tale").
para:intro: First lines read: "There are people in the world who think their lives well employed in collecting shells; there are others not less satisfied to spend theirs in classing butterflies. For my own part, I always preferred animate to inanimate nature; and would rather post to the Antipodes to mark a new character, or develop a singular incident, than become a Fellow of the Royal Society, by enriching museums with non-descripts."
para:footnotes: Footnotes on p. 307 and 332 of Vol. I provide translation of dialogue and a place name written in a foreign language. Both are marked with an asterisk.

author transcribed: By the author of Evelina.
title catalog: Cecilia; or, Memoirs of an heiress. By the author of Evelina.
title full: Cecilia, or memoirs of an heiress. By the author of Evelina. The fourth edition. In five volumes. Vol. I.
pub transcribed: Printed for T. Payne and Son at the Mews-Gate, and T. Cadell in the Strand.
pub cataloger notes: Cf. English novel, 1770-1829, 1782:15 notes for reference to this work. | Cecilia Beverley is an orphan: "Her ancestors had been rich farmers in the county of Suffolk, though her father in whom a spirit of elegance had supplanted the rapacity of wealth, had spent his time as a private country gentleman, satisfied, without increasing his store, to live upon what he inherited from the labours of his predecessors. She had lost him in her early youth and her mother had not long survived him" (p.6). | There is a few lines of a poem on p.21: "For common rules were ne\'er design\'d -- Directors of a noble mind." These lines come from "CADENUS AND VANESSA" by Jonathan Swift written in 1713. There is another poem on p.225: "-----in ten thousand pounds -- Ten thousand charms are centred." | Letters appear in the first volume on the following page numbers: 129, 172, and 173-174. Letters appear in the second volume on the following page numbers: 67, 87-88, and 204. In the third volume, letters appear on pages 28-30, 46, 111, and 112. In the fourth on pages 4-11, 42-43, 46-48, and 139-141. In the fifth on pages 53, 130, 159, 197, 202, and 300-1.
para:advertisement: Reads: "The indulgence shewn by the Public to EVELINA, which, unpatronized, unaided, and unowned, past through Four Editions in one Year, has encouraged its Author to risk this SECOND attempt. The animation of sucess is too universally acknowledged, to make the writer of the following sheets dread much censure of temerity; though the precariousness of any power to give pleasure, suppresses all vanity of confidence, and sends CECILIA into the world with scarce more hope, though far more encouragement, than attended her highly-honoured predecessor, EVELINA."
para:footnotes: Footnotes can be found in Vol. I on p. 22 (attributes a quote to Shakespeare); in Vol. II on p. 49 (indexical), 133 (attributes a quoted line to Mason\'s Elfrida), 166 (attributes a quoted line to Smart); in Vol. IV on p. 167 (two footnotes appear: one clarifies a reference to a figure external to the novel, whereas the second attributes a quoted line to "Life of Crowley"); and in Vol. V on p. 82 (indexical),

author transcribed: By the author of Evelina, and Cecilia ...
title catalog: Camilla: or, A picture of youth. By the author of Evelina, and Cecilia ...
title full: Camilla: or, a picture of youth. By the author of Evelina and Cecilia. In five volumes. Vol. I.
pub transcribed: Printed for T. Payne, at the Mews-Gate; and T. Cadell Jun. and W. Davies (successors to Mr. Cadell) in the Strand.
pub cataloger notes: Bookplate. Located on the frontispiece of all five volumes. "Cervus lacessitus leo." Inscribed by Richard Brinsley Sheridan. | Bookplate - "Library of the University of Pennsylvania.  The Godfrey F. Singer Memorial presented by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Singer."  Located on the recto of the front free end paper, all five volumes. | In Vol. III, p. 61-63 and 157-159 are torn. | Vol. I contains a prefatory chapter which isn\'t listed in the table of contents. "The historian of human life finds less of difficulty and of intricacy to develop, than the investigator of the human heart in its feelings and its changes [...] Fairly, however faintly, to delineate some of its features, is the sole and discriminate province of the pen which would trace nature, yet blot out personality."
para:dedication: First line reads: "Madam, That goodness inspires a confidence, which, by divesting respect of terror, excites attachment to greatness, the presentation of this little work to Your Majesty must truly, however humbly, evince; and though a public manifestation of duty and regard from an obscure individual may betray a proud ambition, it is, I trust, but a venial -- I am sure it is a natural one."
para:advertisement: Alludes to success of Evelina and Cecilia ("The author of this little work cannot [...] refuse herself the indulgence of expressing some portion of the gratitude with which she is filled, by the highly favourable reception given to her two former attempts in this species of composition [...]") before thanking "the Hon. Mrs. Boscawen, Mrs. Crewe, and Mrs. Locke", whose "kind zeal has forwarded the present undertaking [...]"
para:footnotes: On p. 354 of Vol. III and p. 312 and 482 in Vol. V, footnotes attribute quoted lines of text to Dryden, Shakespeare and Young.

author transcribed: published by the author of David Simple : in two volumes.
title catalog: The history of Ophelia / published by the author of David Simple : in two volumes.
title full: The history of Ophelia. Published by the author of David Simple. In two volumes. Vol. I.
pub transcribed: Printed for R. Baldwin, at the Rose, in Pater-Noster-Row
pub cataloger notes: The Author of David Simple is Sarah Fielding.  Cf. Halkett & Laing (2nd ed.) | Advertisements on last page of v. 1. | Work is divided into numbered chapters. Vol. II begins with chapter XXXI (31). | The last page of Vol. II is signed "Your Ladyship\'s most obedient, humble servant, Ophelia Dorchester."
para:advertisement: First lines: "I am obliged to fortune, for the papers I now offer to the publick. I little imagined, when I bought an old buroe, that I was purchasing a work of fancy; for such I must suspect this little work to be, though it contains many incidents that bear so much the appearance of reality, that they might claim some share of our belief."
para:intro: Written in the first person, the introduction is signed by Ophelia, and addresses "Your Ladyship," who evidently compelled the fictional character to write her account: "Your Ladyship had little compassion either on yourself or me, when you desired me to write you an exact account of every circumstance of my life, and even of my thoughts, or you did not consider the long detail into which this lead me [...] You expressly desire to know the impressions I recieved from the first view of customs so unlike what I had ever seen, at a time when they are become so familiar to me, that I almost forgot many of them were ever otherwise."

para:advertisement: "The publisher of this volume is under some difficulties; not from any apprehensions of losing by the book; for great part of the impression is bespoke; his anxiety arises from the author\'s addressing the volume to him, and making him a compliment in the beginning; which, as he is conscious he does not deserve, he hopes the reader will impute to its proper cause, namely, to the warmth of friendship, which is too apt to exhalt the object it esteems. [...]"

The question now afloat in the world respecting things as they are, is the most interesting that can be presented to the human mind. While one party pleads for reformation and change, the other extols in the warmest terms the existing constitution of society."
para:footnotes: Footnotes on p. 208 and 210 appear in volume two after the descriptions of events in the text; they confirm the validity of the circumstances described. The first reads: "An incident exactly similar to this, was witnessed by a friend of the author, a few years since, in Newgate." The second reads: "A story extremely similar to this can be found in the Newgate Calendar, Vol. I p. 282."

pub transcribed: Printed by Thomas Dobson, at the Stone-House, N° 41, South Second-Street
pub cataloger notes: Translation of: L\'an deux mille quatre cent quarante. | Translated by William Hooper. | A perforation of "University of Pennsylvania" appears on pages [i], 99, and 359. | Attributed to Louis-Sebastien Mercier in Barbier, A.A. Ouvrages anonymes. | Library call number appears in pencil on title page. | Running titles change to reflect the chapter title.
para:dedication: Transcription of the opening sentences: "August and venerable year! thou who art to bring felicity upon the earth! thou, alas! that I have only in a dream behled, when thou shalt rise from out the bosom of eternity, thy sun shall enlighten them who will tread upon my ashes, and upon those of thirty generations, successively cut off, and plunged in the profound abyss of death."
para:advertisement: This paratextual essay purports to describe the translation choices, including rounding the original title - "The year two thousand four hundred and forty" - and changing "the names of places and persons, to almost all the capital cities of Europe." (ii).
para:intro: The introduction begins: "That all should be well is the wish of the philsopher [...] Why may not the human race resembe an individual? Touchy, hasty, thoughtless, in youth; gentle, patient, prudent in age*. The man who argues thus imposes on himself the duty of being just [...] For me, concentered with Pato, I dream like him."

title catalog: The democrat; or Intrigues and adventures of Jean le Noir, : from his inlistment as a drummer in General Rochembeau\'s army, and arrival in Boston, to his being driven from England in 1795, after having borne a conspicuous part in the French Revolution, and after a great variety of enterprizes, hazards and escapes during his stay in England, where he was sent in quality of democratic missionary. : In two volumes. Vol. I[-II]. : [Four lines of verse]
title full: The democrat; or intrigues and adventures of Jean le Noir, from his inlistment as a drummer in General Rochembeau\'s army, and arrival at Boston, to his being driven from England in 1795, after having borne a conspicous part in the French Revolution, and after a great variety of enterprizes, hazards, and escapes during his stay in England, where he was sent in quality of democratic missionary. In two volumes. Vol. I
title half: The democrat
pub transcribed: Printed for James Rivington, no. 156 Pearl-Street.,
pub cataloger notes: Attributed to Pye in the Dictionary of national biography. | The two volumes have been bound together in a single volume, with the page numbering starting over in Vol. II. | Vol. 2 ([4], [2], 162,)  has separate title page. | Signatures: A-M6 N2; [A]2 B-O6 P4 (P4 blank). | With a half-title to each volume. | Error in paging: v. 2, p. 134 misnumbered 234. | Error in printing: v. 2, p.155 footnote asterisk becomes a dagger when repeated at the bottom of the page. | Author claim appears in Vol. I on page 17: Author claim type: Author (text); Author claim description: Generic/Descriptive; Author claim transcription: "Nor let my reader wonder here...." (v.1, 17); Location of author claim: Main text; Author gender claim: Indeteriminate. | In addition to including verse, the work includes commentary on the proper reading of poetry and "English versification" (v.1, 74). | University of Pennsylvania Library bookplate on front paste down with the words "Gift of Joseph G. Rosengarten." | University of Pennsylvania imprint in Vol. I, page [iv], 99 and Vol. II, page 160. | Library identification numbers appear stamped in ink in Vol. I page [v] and written in pencil in Vol. I page [iv] and Vol. II, on the verso of the last endpaper. | In the space of the running title, there are brief descriptions of the content of the page.
para:preface: The opening setences read: "In the following work the public are presented with the life and adventures of a democratic missionary, sent from the metropolitan see of sedition and murder at Paris, to progate their principles in a neighboring country. The reception he met with among the different orders of the people, and his awkaward, though zealous endeavours in the cause of liberty and equality, will not fail of yielding the reader an abundance of amusment: but these adventures, besides being in themselves sufficiently diverting, have an additional claim to the attention of the american reader at this moment, when circumstances render them applicable to ourselves."
para:footnotes: Foonotes appear in Vol. I on pages 18, 22, 71, and 128; and in Vol. II on pages 3, 11, 18, 37, 129, 155, 156.

para:preface: Begins by providing historical context for the reader, from "the conquest which Julius Caesar made here." An explanation for the need for this context can be found at the beginning of the second paragraph: "All this former narration is set down to confute the errors of such as are an opinion, as there was never any such man as king Arthur; and, though historians do disagree on their chronologies [...] in the many points which are most material, they do all conclude of the predescessors and sucessors of king Arthur, as I have formerly related."
